awd_titl_txt: Development of Bio-inspired Synthetic Metallohydrolases Based on Theoretical Insights
awd_abstract_narration:
Development of Bio-inspired Synthetic Metallohydrolases Based on Theoretical Insights 

The breaking of chemical bonds in peptides (small proteins) and other biologically-important molecules by reaction with water is important. This reaction, known as hydrolysis, plays a critical role in a wide range of biological, biotechnological, and industrial applications. Nature has devised highly specialized enzymes known as metallohydrolases to enable these reactions. However, most of the natural enzymes work only under specific conditions. The development of efficient, environmentally-friendly, and economical molecules that mimic the natural enzymes is highly desirable. Their design and synthesis is challenging topic of research that requires interdisciplinary cooperation. In this project, Professor Prabhakar, University of Miami, is developing a fundamental understanding of hydrolysis and applying it to the design of synthetic metallohydrolases. This research links the basic chemical reactions involved in these processes to potential biological, biotechnological, and industrial applications. Dr. Prabhakar is also providing educational and research opportunities to members of minority groups at the high school and undergraduate levels. These outreach activities include the Honors and Executive Internship Program (HEIP) of the Miami-Dade County Public Schools, the American Chemical Society's Project SEED (Summer Experiences for the Economically Disadvantaged), a summer workshop (CATCH: Computational and Theoretical Chemistry for High School) and a High School Research Newsletter (HRN). Additionally, undergraduate students are conducting research through two specialized courses and a summer research program. 

With funding from the Chemical Catalysis Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Rajeev Prabhakar of the University of Miami is deriving guiding principles of peptide (-(O=)C-NH-) and phosphoester ((O=)(RO)(RO)(P-O-R)) hydrolysis for the development of efficient bio-inspired synthetic metallohydrolases. These analogues are likely to offer the following advantages over natural enzymes: (1) inexpensive and recyclable, (2) smaller in size with little or no steric constraints, and (3) tunable for specific functions. However, the critical structural and mechanistic information required for their development cannot be readily obtained through existing experimental techniques. In this research, several state-of-the-art theoretical and computational chemistry techniques involving molecular dynamics, quantum mechanics (QM) and hybrid quantum mechanics/molecular mechanics (QM/MM) are integrated with experiments to first derive the guiding principles of peptide and phosphoester hydrolysis and then apply them to design inexpensive, environment friendly, efficient, specific, and catalytic analogues. These calculations are also validating the applicability of different Density Functional Theory (DFT) functionals, force field parameters, and hybrid QM/MM and QM/QM/MM methods with mechanical and electronic embedding schemes on metallohydrolases and their synthetic analogues. In support of the broader impacts of the project, Dr. Prabhakar is actively training and engaging current and future generations of students at the graduate, undergraduate and high school levels from socio-economically- and educationally-disadvantaged families through the Honors and Executive Internship Program (HEIP) of Miami-Dade County Public Schools, the American Chemical Society's Project SEED (Summer Experiences for the Economically Disadvantaged), a summer workshop called CATCH-Computational and Theoretical Chemistry for High School and a High School Research Newsletter (HRN). The undergraduate students are involved in research supported by the NSF and an existing summer program and specialized courses at the University of Miami.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: RET SUPP-Res Exp for Tchr Supp

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit: In this project, we investigated mechanisms of phosphoester hydrolysis by two distinct binuclear metal core containing enzymes, glycerophosphoesterase (GpdQ) and Streptomyces griseus aminopeptidase (SgAP), and different synthetic analogues. The results gleaned from the studies have thus far led to 17 articles in peer-reviewed journals such as ACS Catalysis, Nature Chemistry, Journal of the American Chemical Society, PhysChemChemPhys, Organic Letters, and Journal of Physical Chemistry. In particular, the following two objectives were pursued.

(a) Mechanistic studies of natural metallohydrolases: In this objective, we have investigated hydrolytic mechanisms of the GpdQ and SgAP enzymes (Figure 1). These enzymes exhibit significant chemical promiscuity i.e. GpdQ hydrolyzes all three types (mono-, di- and tri) of phosphoester bonds, while SgAP can degrade both phosphodiester and peptide bonds. Concerning GpdQ, in collaboration with the Schenk group (University of Queensland, Australia) we employed a multistep strategy to investigate the generation of its reaction center and catalytic mechanism.

(b) Mechanistic studies of synthetic metallohydrolases: In this objective, we proposed that the Zn ion interacts in the C-terminal region of a small peptide Clavanin A (IC in Figure 1) and facilitates its association with the cell membrane through a domino model. In a subsequent study, we suggested a hydrolytic mechanism for DNA damage by this complex through the QM/MM (ONIOM) calculations. In collaboration with the Pecoraro group (University of Michigan), we reported a unique strategy to achieve selectivity and reactivity in a de novo designed protein (IS in Figure 1). In collaboration with the Parac-Vogt group (KU Leuven, Belgium), we combined molecular docking and MD simulations to investigate interactions of 1:1 Zr-containing Keggin polyoxometalate (IPO in Figure 1) with four chemically distinct cleavage sites of human serum albumin (HSA) and mechanisms of their hydrolysis. The precise role of the metal ion in phosphodiester hydrolysis was studied through different mechanisms using mononuclear metal-cyclen (IT) complexes of both divalent [Zn2+, Cu2+ and Co2+] and tetravalent [Ce4+, Zr4+ and Ti4+] metals. We also investigated hydrophobic and steric effects of the enzyme like hydrophobic cavity of octa acid (OA) on the structures, dynamics, reactions and electronic properties of small molecules.

These results have also been reviewed in the form of a focus article (WIREs Computational Molecular Science, 2020, also highlighted in Advanced Science News) and a short review (Current Opinion in Green and Sustainable Chemistry). Additionally, the PI has edited an E-book on the topic ?Advances in the Development of Artificial Metalloenzymes.? These results have also been presented in the form of eight talks in conferences and 11 talks in national and international universities by the PI and graduate students.

Broader Impact: In the last three years, the PI had mentored eight graduate students and graduated four of them. Additionally, the PI has supervised 17 undergraduate students including four females and 13 males (three Hispanics and one African American) in his group. Among them, two students received financial support from the NSF for their summer research. Furthermore, the PI has been actively involved in generating scientific interest among high school students and guiding them. Since 2017, he has supervised seven high school students in his group including four Hispanic and one African American females and two Hispanic males. These students have performed research as part of the Honors and Executive Internship Program (HEIP) of the Miami-Dade County Public Schools (MDCPS) and the American Chemical Society's (ACS) Project SEED (Summer Experiences for the Economically Disadvantaged) summer research program. In the last three years, the PI has also organized the NSF-supported summer workshops for high school students and teachers called CATCH- Computational and Theoretical Chemistry for High School. These workshops were attended by 13 teachers and 23 students from 19 different public and private high schools in Miami-Dade County. Among them, 26 were female (including 24 Hispanics and one African American) and 10 were males (including six Hispanics). For the last five years, the CATCH workshop has been officially utilized for the professional development of high school chemistry teachers by the MDCPS. All thirteen chemistry teachers who participated in the workshops were awarded 21 credit points for their professional development. In collaboration with the MDCPS last year, the PI launched a High School Research Journal (HRJ) to provide them a platform to showcase their research. The PI has also participated in the MDCPS ?principal for a day? program to serve as a principal in local high schools. The PI and his group also actively participated in different science fairs, Miami-Dade STEM Expo, Full STEaM Ahead, the undergraduate Research, Creativity, and Innovation Forum, Brain Fair for young children, and Scientific Research Saturdays. The PI also contributed to ?The Power of Science? exhibition at the Phillip and Patricia Frost Museum of Science in Miami last year.


Last Modified: 11/29/2021
Modified by: Rajeev Prabhakar
